sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ› ï¸ Building Your Personal Utility Library

Real-World Context:

Professional programmers don't reinvent the wheel - they build libraries of reusable functions for common tasks. Think of it like a tradesperson's toolbox:

  • ğŸ”§ Math tools: Calculate percentages, averages, find min/max
  • ğŸ“ Text tools: Format strings, count words, validate data
  • ğŸ“Š Data tools: Filter lists, sort data, analyze patterns

Instead of writing the same code over and over, you write it once in a well-designed function and reuse it everywhere!

What You'll Build:

A Personal Utility Library with three categories of functions:

  1. Math Utilities: Common calculations with clear interfaces
  2. Text Utilities: String processing and validation
  3. Data Utilities: Working with lists using map, filter, lambda

Skills You'll Practice:

  • âœ… Writing functions with clear purposes
  • âœ… Using parameters and return values effectively
  • âœ… Applying default arguments for flexibility
  • âœ… Using lambda functions where appropriate
  • âœ… Organizing related functions together
  • âœ… Testing your functions thoroughly

"""
PERSONAL UTILITY LIBRARY
A collection of reusable functions for common tasks
"""

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# MATH UTILITIES
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def calculate_percentage(part, whole, decimal_places=2):
    """Calculate what percentage 'part' is of 'whole'.
    
    Args:
        part: The part value
        whole: The whole value
        decimal_places: Number of decimal places (default: 2)
    
    Returns:
        Percentage as a float, or 0 if whole is 0
    
    Example:
        calculate_percentage(25, 100) â†’ 25.0
        calculate_percentage(1, 3) â†’ 33.33
    """
    if whole == 0:
        return 0.0
    percentage = (part / whole) * 100
    return round(percentage, decimal_places)

def calculate_average(numbers, exclude_zeros=False):
    """Calculate the average of a list of numbers.
    
    Args:
        numbers: List of numbers
        exclude_zeros: If True, ignore zeros in calculation
    
    Returns:
        Average as a float, or 0 if list is empty
    """
    if not numbers:
        return 0.0
    
    if exclude_zeros:
        numbers = [n for n in numbers if n != 0]
        if not numbers:
            return 0.0
    
    return sum(numbers) / len(numbers)

def find_range(numbers):
    """Find the range (difference between max and min).
    
    Args:
        numbers: List of numbers
    
    Returns:
        Dictionary with min, max, and range
    """
    if not numbers:
        return {"min": None, "max": None, "range": None}
    
    minimum = min(numbers)
    maximum = max(numbers)
    
    return {
        "min": minimum,
        "max": maximum,
        "range": maximum - minimum
    }

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# TEXT UTILITIES
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def count_words(text):
    """Count the number of words in text.
    
    Args:
        text: String to analyze
    
    Returns:
        Number of words
    """
    if not text or not text.strip():
        return 0
    return len(text.split())

def title_case(text):
    """Convert text to Title Case (first letter of each word capitalized).
    
    Args:
        text: String to convert
    
    Returns:
        Title-cased string
    """
    return " ".join(word.capitalize() for word in text.split())

def is_valid_email(email):
    """Check if string looks like a valid email address.
    
    Args:
        email: String to validate
    
    Returns:
        True if valid format, False otherwise
    
    Note:
        Simple validation: checks for @ and . in correct positions
    """
    if not email or " " in email:
        return False
    
    if "@" not in email:
        return False
    
    parts = email.split("@")
    if len(parts) != 2:
        return False
    
    username, domain = parts
    if not username or not domain:
        return False
    
    if "." not in domain:
        return False
    
    return True

def truncate_text(text, max_length, suffix="..."):
    """Truncate text to maximum length with suffix.
    
    Args:
        text: String to truncate
        max_length: Maximum length (including suffix)
        suffix: String to append if truncated (default: "...")
    
    Returns:
        Truncated string
    """
    if len(text) <= max_length:
        return text
    
    # Account for suffix length
    cut_point = max_length - len(suffix)
    return text[:cut_point] + suffix

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# DATA UTILITIES (using map, filter, lambda)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def filter_by_criteria(items, criteria):
    """Filter list items using a criteria function.
    
    Args:
        items: List of items to filter
        criteria: Function that returns True/False for each item
    
    Returns:
        Filtered list
    """
    return list(filter(criteria, items))

def transform_items(items, transformation):
    """Transform each item in a list using a function.
    
    Args:
        items: List of items to transform
        transformation: Function to apply to each item
    
    Returns:
        List of transformed items
    """
    return list(map(transformation, items))

def get_unique_items(items):
    """Get unique items from a list, preserving order.
    
    Args:
        items: List possibly containing duplicates
    
    Returns:
        List with duplicates removed, original order preserved
    """
    seen = set()
    result = []
    for item in items:
        if item not in seen:
            seen.add(item)
            result.append(item)
    return result

def sort_by_attribute(items, attribute, reverse=False):
    """Sort a list of dictionaries by a specific attribute.
    
    Args:
        items: List of dictionaries
        attribute: Key to sort by
        reverse: If True, sort descending (default: False)
    
    Returns:
        Sorted list
    """
    return sorted(items, key=lambda item: item.get(attribute, 0), reverse=reverse)


# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Understanding the Utility Library Design

Part 1: Function Design Principles

Every function in this library follows professional design patterns:

  1. Clear, Descriptive Names:
    calculate_percentage()  # Clear what it does
average()              # Too vague, calculate_average() better
  2. Comprehensive Docstrings:
    def calculate_percentage(part, whole, decimal_places=2):
    """Calculate what percentage 'part' is of 'whole'.
    
    Args:
        part: The part value
        whole: The whole value
        decimal_places: Number of decimal places (default: 2)
    
    Returns:
        Percentage as a float
    
    Example:
        calculate_percentage(25, 100) â†’ 25.0
    """
  3. Default Arguments for Flexibility:
    def calculate_average(numbers, exclude_zeros=False):
    # exclude_zeros is optional, defaults to False
    # Makes function flexible for different use cases
  4. Return Meaningful Values:
    def find_range(numbers):
    return {
        "min": minimum,
        "max": maximum,
        "range": maximum - minimum
    }  # Dictionary with named values, not just a tuple
  5. Input Validation:
    if whole == 0:
    return 0.0  # Prevent division by zero

if not numbers:
    return 0.0  # Handle empty list gracefully

Part 2: Math Utilities Breakdown

def calculate_percentage(part, whole, decimal_places=2):
  • ğŸ“Œ part and whole are required
  • ğŸ“Œ decimal_places=2 is optional with sensible default
  • ğŸ“Œ Checks for zero division: if whole == 0:
  • ğŸ“Œ Uses round() to control precision
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns float, not string with % symbol (more reusable)
def calculate_average(numbers, exclude_zeros=False):
  • ğŸ“Œ Optional exclude_zeros parameter for flexibility
  • ğŸ“Œ Uses list comprehension to filter: [n for n in numbers if n != 0]
  • ğŸ“Œ Multiple validation checks for edge cases
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns 0.0 for empty list (better than raising error)

Part 3: Text Utilities Breakdown

def is_valid_email(email):
  • ğŸ“Œ Multiple validation steps
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns boolean (True/False) for clear yes/no answer
  • ğŸ“Œ Checks: spaces, @ symbol, username and domain parts, . in domain
  • ğŸ“Œ Simple validation (not comprehensive regex, but good enough)
def truncate_text(text, max_length, suffix="..."):
  • ğŸ“Œ suffix="..." is customizable default
  • ğŸ“Œ Accounts for suffix length: cut_point = max_length - len(suffix)
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns original if already short enough

Part 4: Data Utilities with Lambda

def filter_by_criteria(items, criteria):
    return list(filter(criteria, items))
  • ğŸ“Œ Takes a function as parameter (higher-order function)
  • ğŸ“Œ criteria can be any function that returns True/False
  • ğŸ“Œ Usage: filter_by_criteria(numbers, lambda x: x > 5)
  • ğŸ“Œ Wraps built-in filter() with meaningful name
def sort_by_attribute(items, attribute, reverse=False):
    return sorted(items, key=lambda item: item.get(attribute, 0), reverse=reverse)
  • ğŸ“Œ Lambda extracts the attribute: item.get(attribute, 0)
  • ğŸ“Œ Uses .get() with default to avoid KeyError
  • ğŸ“Œ reverse parameter passed through to sorted()

Part 5: Testing Best Practices

if __name__ == "__main__":
  • ğŸ“Œ This code only runs when file is executed directly
  • ğŸ“Œ Not run when imported as a module
  • ğŸ“Œ Perfect for testing/demonstration code

The test suite demonstrates:

  • âœ… Testing edge cases (zeros, empty strings, invalid emails)
  • âœ… Testing with different argument combinations
  • âœ… Clear output showing inputs and results
  • âœ… Organized by category for easy reading

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Expand the Utility Library

Challenge: Add three new functions to the utility library, one in each category.

Requirements:

  1. Math Utility - calculate_tax:
    • Parameters: amount (required), tax_rate (default=0.07 for 7%)
    • Return the total amount including tax
    • Include proper docstring
  2. Text Utility - reverse_words:
    • Parameter: text (a sentence)
    • Return the sentence with word order reversed
    • Example: "hello world" â†’ "world hello"
    • Include proper docstring
  3. Data Utility - calculate_statistics:
    • Parameter: numbers (list of numbers)
    • Return a dictionary with: min, max, average, count
    • Handle empty list gracefully
    • Include proper docstring
  4. Test all three functions:
    • Create test cases showing they work correctly
    • Test edge cases (empty inputs, zeros, etc.)

Bonus Challenge:

  • Add a function group_by_length(words) that takes a list of words and returns a dictionary where keys are word lengths and values are lists of words with that length
  • Example: ["hi", "hello", "yo", "hey"] â†’ {2: ["hi", "yo"], 3: ["hey"], 5: ["hello"]}

def calculate_tax(amount, tax_rate=0.07):
    """Calculate total amount including tax.
    
    Args:
        amount: Base amount before tax
        tax_rate: Tax rate as decimal (default: 0.07 for 7%)
    
    Returns:
        Total amount including tax
    
    Example:
        calculate_tax(100) â†’ 107.0
        calculate_tax(100, 0.10) â†’ 110.0
    """
    return amount * (1 + tax_rate)

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# TEXT UTILITY
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def reverse_words(text):
    """Reverse the order of words in a sentence.
    
    Args:
        text: String containing words separated by spaces
    
    Returns:
        String with words in reversed order
    
    Example:
        reverse_words("hello world") â†’ "world hello"
        reverse_words("one two three") â†’ "three two one"
    """
    if not text or not text.strip():
        return ""
    
    words = text.split()
    reversed_words = words[::-1]
    return " ".join(reversed_words)

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

def calculate_statistics(numbers):
    """Calculate comprehensive statistics for a list of numbers.
    
    Args:
        numbers: List of numbers
    
    Returns:
        Dictionary with min, max, average, and count
        Returns None values if list is empty
    
    Example:
        calculate_statistics([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) â†’ 
        {"min": 1, "max": 5, "average": 3.0, "count": 5}
    """
    if not numbers:
        return {
            "min": None,
            "max": None,
            "average": None,
            "count": 0
        }
    
    return {
        "min": min(numbers),
        "max": max(numbers),
        "average": sum(numbers) / len(numbers),
        "count": len(numbers)
    }

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# BONUS: DATA UTILITY

def group_by_length(words):
    """Group words by their length.
    
    Args:
        words: List of strings
    
    Returns:
        Dictionary where keys are lengths and values are lists of words
    
    Example:
        group_by_length(["hi", "hello", "yo"]) â†’ 
        {2: ["hi", "yo"], 5: ["hello"]}
    """
    groups = {}
    
    for word in words:
        length = len(word)
        if length not in groups:
            groups[length] = []
        groups[length].append(word)
    
    return groups

ğŸ“š How Each Function Works:

  1. calculate_tax() - Math Utility:
    def calculate_tax(amount, tax_rate=0.07):
    return amount * (1 + tax_rate)
    • Simple one-line calculation
    • Default tax rate of 7% (0.07)
    • Multiplies by (1 + rate) to add percentage
    • Example: $100 * 1.07 = $107
  2. reverse_words() - Text Utility:
    words = text.split()       # ["hello", "world"]
reversed_words = words[::-1]  # ["world", "hello"]
return " ".join(reversed_words)  # "world hello"
    • Split text into words using .split()
    • Reverse list using slice [::-1]
    • Join back with spaces using " ".join()
    • Handles empty/whitespace strings gracefully
  3. calculate_statistics() - Data Utility:
    return {
    "min": min(numbers),
    "max": max(numbers),
    "average": sum(numbers) / len(numbers),
    "count": len(numbers)
}
    • Returns dictionary with named values (better than tuple)
    • Uses built-in functions: min(), max(), sum(), len()
    • Handles empty list by returning None values
    • All stats in one function call
  4. group_by_length() - BONUS Data Utility:
    groups = {}
for word in words:
    length = len(word)
    if length not in groups:
        groups[length] = []  # Create list for new length
    groups[length].append(word)  # Add word to appropriate list
    • Builds dictionary dynamically
    • Keys are word lengths (integers)
    • Values are lists of words with that length
    • Pattern: check if key exists, create if not, then append

âš ï¸ Common Mistakes:

  1. Forgetting to Return:
    # âŒ WRONG
def calculate_tax(amount, tax_rate=0.07):
    total = amount * (1 + tax_rate)
    # Forgot to return!

# âœ… CORRECT
def calculate_tax(amount, tax_rate=0.07):
    return amount * (1 + tax_rate)
  2. Not Handling Edge Cases:
    # âŒ WRONG - crashes on empty list
def calculate_statistics(numbers):
    return {"average": sum(numbers) / len(numbers)}  # ZeroDivisionError!

# âœ… CORRECT - checks first
def calculate_statistics(numbers):
    if not numbers:
        return {"average": None}
    return {"average": sum(numbers) / len(numbers)}
  3. Mutating Instead of Creating New:
    # âŒ WRONG - modifies original list
def reverse_words_bad(text):
    words = text.split()
    words.reverse()  # Modifies in place!
    return " ".join(words)

# âœ… BETTER - creates new reversed list
def reverse_words(text):
    words = text.split()
    return " ".join(words[::-1])  # New list
  4. Not Testing Edge Cases:
    # Always test:
# - Empty inputs
# - Single item
# - Very large numbers
# - Invalid/unexpected inputs

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips:

  • âœ… One function, one purpose: Each function does exactly one thing
  • âœ… Descriptive names: calculate_tax > tax > t
  • âœ… Default arguments for common cases: 7% tax is common, make it default
  • âœ… Return structured data: Dictionary with named keys > tuple with positions
  • âœ… Validate inputs: Check for empty/None/zero before processing
  • âœ… Test edge cases: Empty inputs, single items, large numbers
  • âœ… Combine functions: Use utilities together for complex tasks

ğŸ“ What You've Learned:

  • How to design professional utility functions
  • Writing comprehensive docstrings
  • Using default arguments effectively
  • Handling edge cases gracefully
  • Returning structured data (dictionaries)
  • Testing functions thoroughly
  • Combining simple functions for complex operations

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Essential Points to Remember:

  1. Professional function design principles:
    • âœ… Clear, descriptive names (verbs for actions)
    • âœ… Comprehensive docstrings (what, parameters, returns, examples)
    • âœ… Default arguments for flexibility
    • âœ… Input validation for edge cases
    • âœ… Return meaningful values (not just print)
  2. Function organization:
    • Group related functions together (Math, Text, Data)
    • One function = one clear purpose
    • Functions should be reusable in different contexts
  3. Docstring format:
    def function_name(param1, param2=default):
    """Brief description of what it does.
    
    Args:
        param1: Description
        param2: Description (default: value)
    
    Returns:
        Description of return value
    
    Example:
        function_name(value) â†’ result
    """
  4. Default arguments make functions flexible:
    def calculate_tax(amount, tax_rate=0.07):
    # Can call: calculate_tax(100)
    # Or: calculate_tax(100, 0.10)
  5. Return structured data for complex results:
    # âŒ OK but unclear
return 10, 50, 30  # What do these mean?

# âœ… BETTER - self-documenting
return {"min": 10, "max": 50, "range": 30}
  6. Always validate inputs:
    if not numbers:  # Empty list
    return None

if whole == 0:  # Division by zero
    return 0.0

if not text or not text.strip():  # Empty/whitespace
    return ""
  7. Higher-order functions are powerful:
    def filter_by_criteria(items, criteria):
    # Takes a FUNCTION as parameter
    return list(filter(criteria, items))

# Usage with lambda
result = filter_by_criteria(numbers, lambda x: x > 5)
  8. Combine simple functions for complex tasks:
    # Each function does one thing well
prices_with_tax = [calculate_tax(p) for p in prices]
stats = calculate_statistics(prices_with_tax)
  9. Testing is essential:
    • Test normal cases
    • Test edge cases (empty, single item, very large)
    • Test with invalid inputs
    • Organize tests by category
  10. The if __name__ == "__main__": pattern:
    • Code inside only runs when file is executed directly
    • Not run when imported as module
    • Perfect place for tests and demonstrations

ğŸ“ Module 6 Complete!

Congratulations! You've mastered functions - one of the most important concepts in programming! You now know:

  • âœ… How to create reusable functions with def
  • âœ… Parameters and return values for communication
  • âœ… Variable scope (local vs global)
  • âœ… Default and keyword arguments for flexibility
  • âœ… Lambda functions for simple operations
  • âœ… Built-in functions like map, filter, sorted
  • âœ… Professional function design and organization

Functions are the building blocks of all programs. Master them and you can build anything!

ğŸš€ Coming Up Next:

In Module 7, you'll learn about Dictionaries and Sets - Python's most powerful data structures for storing and organizing data with keys, values, and unique items!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What should every professional function include?
options: A name, docstring, parameter validation, and return value
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Professional functions should have: (1) Clear descriptive name, (2) Comprehensive docstring explaining what it does, (3) Parameter validation for edge cases, (4) Meaningful return values. This makes functions reusable, maintainable, and easy to understand.

checkpoint_quiz.question: Why is returning a dictionary better than returning a tuple for complex results?
options: Dictionary keys make the values self-documenting
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Returning {'min': 10, 'max': 50} is SELF-DOCUMENTING - you immediately know what each value represents. With a tuple (10, 50), you have to remember or check which position is min and which is max. Dictionary keys make code more readable and maintainable.

checkpoint_quiz.question: What does 'if __name__ == "__main__":' do?
options: Checks if the function name is 'main'
Code only runs when file is executed directly, not when imported
It's required for all Python programs
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Code inside 'if __name__ == "__main__":' only runs when the file is executed DIRECTLY (python myfile.py), not when imported as a module. This is perfect for test code and demonstrations - the functions are available for import, but tests don't run automatically.
